headlines.title: OpenAI reportedly partners with Broadcom to mass‑produce custom AI chips
OpenAI eyes a 1‑gigawatt data center footprint in India
Greece inks deal with OpenAI to bring AI to schools and SMEs

stories.title: OpenAI reportedly partners with Broadcom to mass‑produce custom AI chips
stories.body:
OpenAI is moving toward mass production of its own AI accelerators with Broadcom, according to the
Financial         Times. The goal: secure long‑term compute at lower cost and reduce reliance on
Nvidia while tuning hardware         tightly to OpenAI’s model workloads. A custom silicon push
would echo strategies at Google and Amazon, and         could alter cloud economics if yields and
software stacks mature.                  The near‑term impact is strategic—preparing capacity for
the next generation of multimodal and agent models.         For enterprises, a diversified AI‑chip
market could mean more pricing power and availability across providers.

stories.title: OpenAI eyes a 1‑gigawatt data center footprint in India
stories.body:
OpenAI is reportedly planning a data‑center buildout in India with at least 1 gigawatt of power—an
enormous         footprint aimed at training and serving next‑gen models. The project would tap
India’s growing role in global         cloud infrastructure and align with the country’s push to
host more AI workloads domestically.                  Big picture: hyperscale AI now hinges on
power, cooling, and supply chains. If sited well, a 1‑GW campus         could accelerate OpenAI’s
capacity and boost India’s AI ecosystem from chips to talent.

stories.title: Greece inks deal with OpenAI to bring AI to schools and SMEs
stories.body:
Greece and OpenAI agreed to collaborate on AI tools for education and small businesses, with pilots
planned         for classrooms and digitization projects for SMEs. Officials say the partnership
will focus on safe use,         teacher training, and practical tools that raise productivity in the
public and private sectors.                  Why it matters: Europe’s AI landscape will be shaped as
much by local deployments as by flagship models.         Greece’s move could become a template for
rolling out classroom‑ready AI under EU rules.

headlines.title: EU hits Google with €2.95B ad‑tech fine: what changes now
Apple’s Sept 9 ‘Awe dropping’ iPhone 17 event: what to expect
Dyson’s Spot+Scrub Ai robot vacuum debuts with stain‑seeking mop

stories.title: EU hits Google with €2.95B ad‑tech fine: what changes now
stories.body:
European regulators have fined Google €2.95 billion ($3.5B) for abusing dominance in
ad‑tech—accusing it of         steering advertisers and publishers toward its own tools. Brussels’
decision could force structural remedies         if Google’s proposed fixes fall short, including a
potential spin‑out of parts of its ad stack. Google says it         will appeal.
Why it matters: ads fund much of the free web. If Google must open access or divest, competitors
could win         share in ad exchanges, while publishers might see improved yield from a more
neutral auction. In the near         term, marketers should plan for data‑sharing changes, auction
transparency requirements, and new policies that         reduce self‑preferencing—shifts likely to
ripple across analytics and attribution stacks.

stories.title: Apple’s Sept 9 ‘Awe dropping’ iPhone 17 event: what to expect
stories.body:
Apple’s next keynote is set for September 9 (1 p.m. ET) with ‘Awe dropping’ branding—and all signs
point to         the iPhone 17 line and new Apple Watches. Expect Pro‑class camera updates
(telephoto moves on Pro/Max),         A‑series chip gains, and iOS refinements tuned for on‑device
AI features. Case makers are already showing         dummy units at IFA, and the rumor mill suggests
at least one watch with satellite messaging for off‑grid         texts. Pricing and availability
should lock the same day.                  For buyers, the calculus is simple: if you skipped iPhone
15/16, the 17’s camera and battery bumps (plus         smarter photo/video pipelines) could be the
nudge. We’ll update this story with confirmed specs after the         event.

stories.title: Dyson’s Spot+Scrub Ai robot vacuum debuts with stain‑seeking mop
stories.body:
Dyson unveiled the Spot+Scrub Ai, its first combo vacuum‑mop robot, at IFA Berlin. The round‑body
bot adds a         self‑cleaning wet roller, lidar navigation, object recognition, and a
multifunction “Cyclonic Dock” that         empties, washes, dries and refills—aiming to compete with
Roborock and Ecovacs at the premium tier. Dyson         touts stain detection and before/after
verification to prove it actually scrubbed the spot.                  Why it’s interesting: the
dock‑centric design reduces weekly maintenance, and the verification snaps could         help
consumers trust “AI cleaning” claims. If Dyson sticks the software and price, this could be the
brand’s         first true hit in robot cleaning hardware.

headlines.title: Kangaroos stage a jailbreak in Waco—police lend a hand
New Haven wants a Guinness record for the world’s largest pizza party
Robot waiters are having a moment—cutesy cats deliver sushi and smiles

stories.title: Kangaroos stage a jailbreak in Waco—police lend a hand
stories.body:
A wildlife rescue in Waco, Texas, had a literal hopping emergency when multiple kangaroos escaped
their         enclosure. Local police joined staff in rounding up the marsupials, and the facility
later confirmed that all         the roos were accounted for and unharmed. Social media did its
thing—puns and ‘pouch patrol’ memes flew—while         the rescue promised sturdier fencing.
The best part: impromptu neighborhood videos of kangaroos bouncing down suburban streets. Only in
Texas.

stories.title: New Haven wants a Guinness record for the world’s largest pizza party
stories.body:
Can the pizza‑proud city of New Haven out‑slice Tulsa? Organizers of the A‑1 Toyota Apizza Feast
think so—         they’re attempting to feed 5,000 people two slices each on September 12 in a bid
to shatter the Guinness World         Record for largest pizza party. Dozens of trucks from local
icons like Pepe’s and Sally’s will set up on the         Green, with proceeds supporting local
causes.                  Expect cycling races, a pizza relay, and many full bellies. Guinness
adjudicators will be watching every bite.

stories.title: Robot waiters are having a moment—cutesy cats deliver sushi and smiles
stories.body:
Need a table run? In Japan—and increasingly in the U.S.—restaurants are deploying robot waiters with
animated         cat faces to ferry plates and charm customers. The bots don’t replace servers so
much as bridge staffing gaps,         gliding between tables while humans handle hospitality. Videos
of the “cat‑bots” keep going viral, and the         novelty hasn’t worn off yet.
Are they practical? Operators say yes for steady routes and simple tasks. And yes, kids love them.

headlines.title: WHO: Mpox is no longer a global emergency
Study: Clopidogrel may beat aspirin in preventing heart attacks and strokes
Inflammation markers tied to heart risk in women without classic factors

stories.title: WHO: Mpox is no longer a global emergency
stories.body:
The World Health Organization says mpox no longer meets the criteria for a Public Health Emergency
of         International Concern, citing improved surveillance and vaccination. The virus still
warrants vigilance,         especially in vulnerable communities, but the downgrade reflects
declining severe cases and better outbreak         management.                  For public health
officials, the message is steady: keep up testing, vaccination, and engagement with         at‑risk
populations to prevent flare‑ups.

stories.title: Study: Clopidogrel may beat aspirin in preventing heart attacks and strokes
stories.body:
A new analysis suggests clopidogrel could outperform aspirin for secondary prevention of heart
attacks and         strokes in some patients. Researchers found lower rates of composite
cardiovascular events among those on         clopidogrel, though doctors stress that individual
risk, tolerability, and cost remain critical factors.                  If guidelines shift, millions
could see their go‑to antiplatelet therapy change in the coming years.

stories.title: Inflammation markers tied to heart risk in women without classic factors
stories.body:
New research highlights inflammation as a key driver of serious cardiac events among some women who
lack         traditional risk factors like high cholesterol or hypertension. Elevated inflammatory
markers correlated with         higher event rates, pointing clinicians toward broader screening and
prevention strategies.                  The takeaway: heart risk can hide in plain sight—ask your
doctor about inflammation metrics if you have         symptoms or family history.
